ARTICLE.TITLE: Donald Trump Says TikTok Deal Must Benefit U.S. And Ensure ‘Total Security’
ARTICLE.TEXT:
The US president Donald Trump had announced that TikTok, a popular short-video app would be banned in the country starting September 15, unless an American company purchases the app. Soon after, the reports around Microsoft’s TikTok deal started to make the rounds. And now, President Donald Trump has emphasized that any deal to sell TikTok to an American company will have to ensure "total security" and should "substantially" benefit the United States.

SEE ALSO: Facebook, Snap Showed Interest In Purchasing TikTok Rival Dubsmash: Report

As reported by PTI, Donald Trump told reporters at the White House that they have set a deadline for ban on TikTok to September 15. “Whether it's Microsoft, I understand — and others are negotiating — we also said that, obviously, it's worthless if we don't allow them into the country, so we said that the United States treasury is going to be getting something out of this deal — something very substantial," said Trump, as per a PTI report. He also added that he wants “total security” and any deal around TikTok would need to be proven to be totally secure. He further emphasized that he doesn’t want any data to be accessed by China.

Microsoft had revealed recently that it’s currently in negotiations with ByteDance to explore Global TikTok deal around the U.S., Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and more. Now, there are reports that ByteDance is in talks with India’s Reliance for investment in the short-video app that’s now banned in the country. India had banned TikTok along with over 50 other Chinese apps citing user data privacy reasons. According to the Indian government, the ban action was taken to ensure the “safety and sovereignty of Indian cyberspace”.

SEE ALSO: TikTok Rap Captures The UK's Entire Mood Right Now

China has called the US plans for the purchase of a video app as “theft”, stating it won’t accept it. It also stated that China had “plenty of ways to respond if the administration carries out its planned smash and grab”, as per a report in a state-backed newspaper, China Daily.

There have also been recent reports that TikTok's US employees are preparing file a lawsuit to sue Trump administration executive order, citing reasons that it’s currently unclear as to whether the order would make it illegal for their employer TikTok to pay them.
